Review Title: Work here if you want to get screwed out of our pay
Pros: Met some really nice folks, but that has 0 to do with Nutanix
Cons: Sales goals moved constantly, compensation plans not adhered to and will get rid of you before you collect that big windfall you worked hard for. Sham product, Sham leadership. Can we tell the customers about the scale problems? Or cyber issues? Cannot WAIT for the IG investigations coming. And for the love of GOD, don't EVER consider an International assignment. I know someone who just came back writing a tell all about how Nutanix is just a bad company to work for and bad equipment to own. I hope Cisco buys them and kills the product.

Pros: Nice office environment, opportunity for growth
Cons: Leadership only favored who they liked

Review Title: Unethical and Autocratic Management, Compensation Cuts
Pros: As usually the case, there is a standard of good people and technology here.
Cons: Unsuspecting candidates are lured into working here under the pretense that benefits are better than industry standards, then unceremoniously reduce them and inadequately adjust compensation. Management then attempts to hide this through censorship, removing VERY popular Slack channels and replacing with moderated ones. Worse is senior management are so out of touch they think employees won't figure this out. Company has a LONG way to go to be considered truly enterprise class. Recent decisions and moves have brought into question their competence to get us there. Company isn't profitable and management can't figure out why. Management lack of business acumen taken out on workforce.

Review Title: Support is a well run organization
Pros: Benefits are fantastic. They are adding 401k match in Jan. Management moves fast on internal support changes. Iteration is the norm. Upper managerment seems to have our backs and Support Managers are a team with little politics. Ample opportunity for training
Cons: Premiums are being added for healthcare, but still 100% covered for employee.

Pros: Worked remotely for the Custimer Marketing team - had positive experiences in terms of compensation, work quality, life/work balance, and team culture.
Cons: I was a FT contractor and wasn’t given a clear contract to hire progression outline

Executive leadership consistently prioritizes profitability, often to the detriment of customer satisfaction and employee morale.

Review Title: Really great people and benefits, but comp is pretty sad
Pros: The people I work with are all really great, I love my work and the benefits offered are really strong
Cons: But during this promotion cycle, everyone is now severely underpaid. They barely offered merit raises, and even for those who got promotions, they barely got a raise, citing economic issues. I'm sorry but most of these "economic issues" have eased, and we're doing well as a company. I don't know how you justify not even really giving any sort of raise to an employee when you promote them. Pay your people, or they'll leave, it's very disingenuous

Review Title: It was a very organized, well planned and enjoyable experience.
Pros: - Although 5 interviews seems like a long road, we had a very enjoyable time with the people I met in each interview. - It was a well planned process from start to finish. - Everyone was very warm and constructive. - A process where you feel very good how much the company values ​​its employees. - The questions in the technical interview were really meant to measure the level of knowledge.
Cons: There is no cons that I can say

Review Title: Beware - Terrible Senior Leaders Do Not Care About Employees
Pros: Platform is good, works as advertised and designed by prior founding CEO and product teams.
Cons: New senior leadership since Bain Capital took over the reigns, they are terrible. They have no regard for employee welfare or their personal quality of life. I watched leadership time and time again betray employee trust, not follow through on compensation plans when employees over exceeded goals and they are morally bankrupt as human beings and leaders. I left the team as one their Top 5% performers.

Cons: The move to ACV and stripping renewals away really hurt the field sales org, as well as moved the field teams farther away from the customers. This was also associated with a very poo quota adjustment that caused most top talent to leave.

Cons: Significant micromanagement in day-to-day. No growth in or outside of the role, lots of moving goalposts. Poor management and poor culture. No flexibility in remote work, required to be in office Wed-Thurs as of May 2023. Will be required to be in office Tues-Thurs. Specifically for SREs, 18 month tenure required before internal role change. All other roles require 12 months.

Review Title: Fantastic product; horrible back-stabbing culture in some departments

Pros:
Lots of smart people to work with. Product is recognized in the industry and expertise with Nutanix is sought-after.

Starting pay is strong, and healthcare package (as of 2022) is incredibly good, especially for family.

Focus is on competency, in North Carolina. Having a fancier degree doesn't get you any more attention/special treatment, and talented folks with less formal credentials get their shot to be experts. Strong social diversity in hiring.
Cons:
Nutanix privately sold a bunch of equity to Bain in late 2020, after which things started going downhill:
* Within 18 months, SREs were expected to have twice the output, with no compensation changes.

* CEO left the company around this time, "totally unrelated." Company doubled down on its aims and rhetoric around becoming profitable. Obviously the company needs to be profitable to survive, but in my opinion they are doing so at the cost of intangibles - customer loyalty, product quality, employee wellness.

* Company culture is being gutted if it is not reportable/justifiable. Employees are given less agency and less time to be creative. Middle managers gaslight any employees who point out recent changes.

--- GENERAL ---

* Salaries are suppressed. I made more money as a recently-hired SRE 2 than several SRE 3s I spoke with, who had stayed at the company 5+ years. 

* For Support specifically: Middle managers are disorganized and uncoordinated. Support leadership has no agency to secure the needs of the SREs. Healthcare package will likely be watered down within 5 years.

Cons: Food and coworkers are nice

Cons: No clear strategy within the team.

Review Title: Nutanix had it going on for a while
Pros: - Market disrupter, amazing technology, the best support in the business. - Amazing team especially the early days. - Straightforward comp plan - Excellent benefits
Cons: - The move from TCV pay to ACV pay was terrible (paying for the total value of the deal, versus just the software value of the deal). Quotas did not adjust. It was a massive quota hike, in effect. - Took too long to integrate/work with Red Hat and Microsoft Azure.

Pros: Good healthcare, free snacks and drinks
Cons: Everything else - the company is terribly run

Pros:
•Great product 
•Fantastic support and engineering 
•New leadership and fresh blood that is ready to work to make us more profitable and the best out there!

Like everywhere in this great resignation era culture- we have had some turnover. However, I think it was all for the better of the company. The employees that had been here 5+ years had been resting on their laurels - hiding out. Most were not interested in truly digging in and working hard. 
With new leadership and changes in the sales, marketing, and engineering teams in past 18 months - I think we are going to be even better!
Cons: Change means different process and culture

Review Title: Strap in, hold on, pedal hard... get ready for an amazing ride!
Pros:
-Culture. Such a cliche term, but the people here are genuinely good people, working together to disrupt the IT industry. Not a cut throat environment, we’re all pushing in the same direction.

-Challenge. If you love to be stretched, challenged, trusted, pushed to your limit then you’ll thrive in this company.

-Compensation. Pay is competitive, benefits are covered 100%, stock and ESPP give an added bump. 

-Management. There are some really good managers and mentors at Nutanix, if you’re aligned to them then you’ll love your job. The executive leadership of the company is 2nd to none.
Cons:
-Culture. If you want structure, clear growth paths, to move up the chain quickly and your value is based on your title and praise... we’re not there yet. Everyone is so focused on getting the work done that we don’t spend a lot of time on employee recognition and development. Career growth and development are pushed by HR but their not structured or adopted enough to be mainstream.  

-Challenge. The fast pace and demand is not for the light hearted. If you thrive in that type of environment you’ll be happy here.

-Management. There are a lot of team managers who are stronger individual contributors than they are managers. Advice: really do your homework on who you’ll be reporting to and what their management style is.

Pros: Great benefits. Some good people.
Cons: Quote a bit of dead wood and a lack of clear strategy.

Pros: The Technology at Nutanix is great.
Cons: Most people at Nutanix hate their job. The culture has declined over the past 6 months or so due to the hiring of VMWare sales leadership. It has become VMWare 2.0

Review Title: Good company but stock growth is disappointing
Pros: - Work culture - Innovative projects -
Cons: - Stock growth is disappointing

Pros: Benefits are top notch. Really well run marketing in region - tremendous events for sellers to bring prospects to.
Cons: GTM versus VmWare very poor and challenging.

Pros: I started at Nutanix pre-IPO and when it was relatively small (<500 employees). Benefits were great, pay was at market for the time, and going through the IPO process was pretty cool. The culture for the first few years was amazing, nothing like I've ever experienced. Early on, the product worked well, was simple and was differentiated among a competitive market.
Cons: Post-IPO is when things started to change. There was lots of "leadership" brought in from other big-name competitors which changed the culture drastically and that started a mass-exodus of existing leadership and employees that were there for a long time. The product become overly complex and riddled with bugs. Once the pricing structure changed, the products became too expensive for what they were, even with drastic discounting. If you were fortunate enough to sell and make your quota, renewals were ridiculously expensive and renewal rates plummeted. Territories were split (even smaller markets) and new teams were brought in to "increase revenue", which did nothing more than invoke backstabbing in the field across GEO's and verticals. Execs will talk at length about the Annual Contract Value (ACV) growth, but when you really look at overall revenue over the last several years, it's quite stagnate.

Pros: Great people, collaborative, smart, helpful
Cons: A bit behind the competition

Pros: No pros for working at Nutanix.
Cons: Poor Management, no work-life balance.
